results.summary: A 23-year-old man charged with murdering two Big Issue sellers who were stabbed in the centre of Birmingham is remanded in custody.
results.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/54db04db-1fee-5044-b5c8-da7a56a463f9"><image id="65251617"/><paragraph role="introduction">A man charged with murdering two Big Issue sellers who were stabbed in the centre of Birmingham has been remanded in custody.</paragraph><paragraph>John Ward, 23, of no fixed address, was remanded until Wednesday by Birmingham Magistrates' Court.</paragraph><paragraph>Wayne Busst, 32, and Ian Gladwish, 31, both from the city, were stabbed in Union Street shortly before 18:00 GMT on Friday.</paragraph><paragraph>Despite first aid from passers-by and police officers they died at the scene.</paragraph><paragraph>One of the men was stabbed outside Sainsbury's in Union Street, while the other was found slumped nearby outside a side entrance to Boots.</paragraph><paragraph>Police had said there could have been hundreds of witnesses to the stabbings.</paragraph><paragraph>The families of both victims have paid tribute to the men.</paragraph><crosshead>'Hope for justice'</crosshead><paragraph>A statement from Mr Busst's family read: "We are deeply saddened by Wayne's death, he will be greatly missed by all his family and all that knew him. </paragraph><paragraph>"We also think of Ian's family as they share in the grief at this sad time. </paragraph><paragraph>"We ask the press to respect the family's request for privacy at this time, so that we can grieve in peace. </paragraph><image id="65250387"/><paragraph>"The family would ask any member of the public with information that may assist the police investigation come forward." </paragraph><paragraph>The family of Mr Gladwish said: "Ian was a husband, son, brother and dad. He was a kind loving person.</paragraph><paragraph>"To be taken away from us in these circumstances has left us all devastated, we will miss him dearly. </paragraph><paragraph>"We would like to thank everybody for their support during this difficult time and request that we are left to grieve in peace. </paragraph><paragraph>"Our sincerest condolences also go out to Wayne's family." </paragraph><paragraph>Big Issue founder and editor-in-chief John Bird also paid tribute to the two vendors and said everyone at the magazine was "absolutely devastated".</paragraph><paragraph>Mr Bird said: "They were very, very popular with our office staff there and had worked as vendors for a long time."</paragraph></body>
